{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2941535,"name":"Micah Guttman","username":"memtech3","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/41988e/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-03-21T22:34:23.990Z","cooked":"

Is there a good way to control a spark max from a microcontroller? My team is considering creating a brushed/brushless motor tester with a spark max that would be able to spin a motor without a computer and was wondering if there was a good way to change motor modes (brushed, brushless, coast, brake) from a microcontroller like an arduino.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2021-03-21T22:59:56.711Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1816,"reads":231,"readers_count":230,"score":9121.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":392652,"topic_slug":"spark-max-motor-tester-controlling-spark-max-from-microcontroller","display_username":"Micah Guttman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":38591,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5892 | Alum"},"post_url":"/t/spark-max-motor-tester-controlling-spark-max-from-microcontroller/392652/1","custom_user_title":"5892 | Alum","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":2941540,"name":"Carlos Gross Jones","username":"CarlosGJ","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/carlosgj/{size}/131747_2.png","created_at":"2021-03-21T22:58:31.416Z","cooked":"

Well, you can do basic speed control if you just use PWM. The microcontroller couldn‚Äôt change brushed/brushless or brake/coast, but you can do that manually with the button.

If you really need to control those things from the microcontroller, you‚Äôd need to implement a CAN interface. That‚Äôs certainly doable; you‚Äôd need a CAN controller, either a standalone IC like an MCP2515, or a microcontroller with CAN built in. The PIC18F2580 has one, and so does the Jetson Nano if you want a more powerful computer (the CAN bus isn‚Äôt brought out on the Nano dev board though, IIRC). Then you‚Äôd need a CAN phy, like the MCP2551. But the challenging part is the software: the FRC format is published, but you‚Äôd have to figure out the definitions for all of the Spark command & telemetry packets. Rev is a little more open about stuff like that than CTRE, at least. It would be a lot easier to do the control from something like a Pi or a Nano, since I think Rev publishes ARM binaries.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2021-03-21T22:58:31.416Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":12,"reads":226,"readers_count":225,"score":110.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":392652,"topic_slug":"spark-max-motor-tester-controlling-spark-max-from-microcontroller","display_username":"Carlos Gross Jones","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16115,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mere hours of work can save you entire minutes of planning"},"post_url":"/t/spark-max-motor-tester-controlling-spark-max-from-microcontroller/392652/2","custom_user_title":"Mere hours of work can save you entire minutes of planning","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2941541,"name":"Micah Guttman","username":"memtech3","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/41988e/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-03-21T22:59:43.033Z","cooked":"

Is there a better way to go about this project?

Well, what are your actual requirements?

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2021-03-21T23:00:50.725Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":14,"reads":193,"readers_count":192,"score":113.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":392652,"topic_slug":"spark-max-motor-tester-controlling-spark-max-from-microcontroller","display_username":"Carlos Gross Jones","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":38591,"username":"memtech3","name":"Micah Guttman","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/41988e/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16115,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mere hours of work can save you entire minutes of planning"},"post_url":"/t/spark-max-motor-tester-controlling-spark-max-from-microcontroller/392652/4","custom_user_title":"Mere hours of work can save you entire minutes of planning","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2941543,"name":"Micah Guttman","username":"memtech3","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/41988e/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-03-21T23:03:38.901Z","cooked":"

We are trying to create a more advanced, all in one, drill tester for brushed and brushless motors. We were thinking of using the drill‚Äôs battery to provide power and a microcontroller like an esp32/arduino/pi pico to take the drill‚Äôs trigger and convert it to a pwm signal to set the motor‚Äôs speed. We are also thinking of keeping the usb c port exposed or using an extender cable so that we can hook the tester up to a computer for more advanced testing, like PID tuning but we want to make sure that the tester can run independently.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2021-03-21T23:03:38.901Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":16,"reads":191,"readers_count":190,"score":128.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":392652,"topic_slug":"spark-max-motor-tester-controlling-spark-max-from-microcontroller","display_username":"Micah Guttman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":16115,"username":"CarlosGJ","name":"Carlos Gross Jones","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/carlosgj/{size}/131747_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":38591,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5892 | Alum"},"post_url":"/t/spark-max-motor-tester-controlling-spark-max-from-microcontroller/392652/5","custom_user_title":"5892 | Alum","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2941544,"name":"Micah Guttman","username":"memtech3","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/41988e/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-03-21T23:04:51.618Z","cooked":"

Also if I‚Äôm lucky I would like to implement a USB over Bluetooth or other wireless bridge so that the controller can be controlled from a computer without a cable

Yes, that would work fine. Any microcontroller should be able to generate PWM, you‚Äôll just need to remember to use the button on the Max to set it to brushed or brushless mode, depending on the motor you‚Äôre trying to run.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2021-03-22T00:17:27.793Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":61,"reads":178,"readers_count":177,"score":345.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":392652,"topic_slug":"spark-max-motor-tester-controlling-spark-max-from-microcontroller","display_username":"Carlos Gross Jones","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":38591,"username":"memtech3","name":"Micah Guttman","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/41988e/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16115,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mere hours of work can save you entire minutes of planning"},"post_url":"/t/spark-max-motor-tester-controlling-spark-max-from-microcontroller/392652/7","custom_user_title":"Mere hours of work can save you entire minutes of planning","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":true,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2941551,"name":"Mykah","username":"ExploitSage","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/exploitsage/{size}/179189_2.png","created_at":"2021-03-22T00:03:10.004Z","cooked":"

Basically just look up how to control Servos from your Micro-controller of Choice. Only gotcha/additional consideration is some Motor Controllers use slightly different PWM Signal Ranges than standard Servos, but nearly every library allows you to set those ranges, so you just need to look up the correct ranges for your Motor Controller of choice.

AndyMark also sells the Thrifty Throttle 3 which is a dedicated handheld tool for generating PWM signals and is powered from a 9v.

That pretty much solves my problem, I didn‚Äôt know that the button could set the brake mode and motor mode

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2021-03-22T00:17:58.267Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":14,"reads":156,"readers_count":155,"score":101.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":392652,"topic_slug":"spark-max-motor-tester-controlling-spark-max-from-microcontroller","display_username":"Micah Guttman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":16115,"username":"CarlosGJ","name":"Carlos Gross Jones","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/carlosgj/{size}/131747_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":38591,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5892 | Alum"},"post_url":"/t/spark-max-motor-tester-controlling-spark-max-from-microcontroller/392652/9","custom_user_title":"5892 | Alum","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2941564,"name":"Chris Herzog","username":"zog","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zog/{size}/266762_2.png","created_at":"2021-03-22T01:06:16.495Z","cooked":"

Here is software for a 4-headed controller (meaning it can run 4 PWM outputs at once) using an Arduino - I used an Uno but so long as you can scrape up the I/O pins, you‚Äôre good with most anything.

Each input has it‚Äôs own speed control and 2 enable input - we use a spring loaded rocker switch to select either fwd or rev so that if you take you finger off the button, the motor stops. Since it‚Äôs target use is to test prototype mechanisms, I considered that sort of a fail safe.

github.com

JolietCyborgs4241/NEOS_arduino_pot_control

master/cyborgs_pwm_motor_driver

A sample program to drive a Rev SPARK brushless controller using PWM from an rduino controlled by a pot with Fwd/Stop/Rev indicator LEDs

It‚Äôs not super sophisticated and was intended to be a stop gap until we made the ‚Äúreally cool one‚Äù - turned out this worked pretty well, well enough that we just moved on to more pressing projects.

I couldn‚Äôt find a pick of the PWM one but it was based on the same form factor as this one which uses inexpensive PWN modules to drive DC motors - https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/519011249376198667/661050460806971418/20191229_212408_1_1.mp4

I‚Äôm pretty sure these are the rockers we used - I‚Äôve got a CAD file for the 3D printer front panel handy as well - 3-Position Momentary Rocker Switch 6-Pin Spring Return DPDT 16A 250V Car Hoist 642610527579 | eBay. The springs are a little stiffer than I would have liked but they fit the bill.

It‚Äôs powered by a robot battery and has an SB series connector on it - figure that was the cheapest 12V power source in the shop.

‚Äì Chris Herzog - Joliet Cyborgs #4241

Take it, run with it, make it cooler, and share it back with the FRC world‚Ä¶

[ FRC 2151 + 3061 | Ri3D Redux '23 | RIP 4292 & 4241 ]","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2941572,"name":"Micah Guttman","username":"memtech3","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/41988e/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-03-22T01:42:02.297Z","cooked":"

I am imagining taking an old drill, cutting a spark max + motor info circuit (Visualise ESC Problems With LEDs | Hackaday) sized hole in the top with a cnc or precision mill, milling or bending a piece of lexan to have the same curvature as the drill body, milling out the inside of the piece to perfectly fit the top of the spark max and motor info circuit, making a captive button presser to push the mode select button, adding a tiny Arduino to take the trigger value and forward/backward switch and convert that to a pwm value, adding panel mount powerpoles to the front of the tester, and setting up the forward/reverse/off switch to kill power to the entire tester when in the off position.

Ideally there would be no hot glue, proper screws, and iron smoothed 3d printed parts

That Hackaday article was incredibly simple but super useful - inspired my to whip up my own the same day! This is what I came up with - Brushless Motor Controller Tester - Control System - Chief Delphi

My realities seem to involve more hot glue than I‚Äôd like - well at least at Rev 0 of a job like you‚Äôre talking about

With restrictions at our school, as a mentor, I‚Äôve been remotely attending meetings as we‚Äôve gotten them started again and I‚Äôm basically going out of my mind not being able to directly mess with the robot

Good luck - share what you do. Don‚Äôt let the super cool idea get in the way of doing something simpler that might be useful now. Just having a way to be able to run mechanisms slowly and in a controlled way paid off huge for our team‚Ä¶
